name.text: Coordinate Rotation: Converting Points between Two Coordinate Systems

questiontext.text:
Suppose the xy-coordinate axes are rotated \( {@Angle_of_rot@} ^ { \circ } \) counterclockwise about the origin to obtain the new \(x^{ \prime } y^{ \prime } \)-coordinate system. If the following points are with respect to the new \(x^{ \prime } y^{ \prime } \)- system, what is the coordinates of each point with respect to the old \(x\,y\)-system?

(a) \( ({@x_a@}, {@y_a@}) \)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

(b) \( ({@x_b@}, {@y_b@}) \)

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

(c) \( ({@x_c@},{@y_c@}) \)

[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

(d) \( ({@x_d@} ,{@y_d @}) \)

[[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

To convert coordinates from the rotated system \( (x^{ \prime}, y ^{ \prime } ) \) back to the original system \( (x, y) \), we need to perform a clockwise rotation by the same angle. In this case, the angle of rotation is \( {@Angle_of_rot@} \) degrees counterclockwise, so we'll perform a clockwise rotation of \( {@Angle_of_rot@} \) degrees to get back to the original system.

The formula to rotate a point \( (x, y) \) by an angle \( \theta \) counterclockwise is:

\( x^{ \prime}= x \, \cos(\theta) - y \, \sin(\theta) \)

\( y^{ \prime} = x \, \sin(\theta) + y \, \cos(\theta) \)

Since we want to go from \( (x^{ \prime}, y^{ \prime} ) \) to \( (x, y) \), we'll substitute \( -\theta \) (clockwise rotation) and use the same trigonometric functions:

\( x = x^{ \prime} \, \cos(-\theta) - y^{ \prime} \, \sin(-\theta) \)

\( y = x^{ \prime} \, \sin(-\theta) + y^{ \prime} \, \cos(-\theta) \)

Given \( \theta = {@Angle_of_rot@} \) degrees, or \( {@Angle_in_pi@} \) radians, the trigonometric values are:

\( \cos({@Angle_in_pi@}) = {@a1@} \)

\( \sin({@Angle_in_pi@}) = {@a2@} \)

\( \cos(-{@Angle_in_pi@})= {@a3@} \)

\( \sin(-{@Angle_in_pi@}) = {@a4@} \)

Let's apply this to each given point:

(a) \( ({@x_a@}, {@y_a@}) \) :

\( x = {@x_a@} \cdot ({@a3@}) - ({@y_a@}) \cdot ({@a4@}) = {@ta1[1]@} \)

\( y = {@x_a@} \cdot ({@a4@}) + ({@y_a@}) \cdot ({@a3@}) = {@ta1[2]@} \)

So, the coordinates of this point with respect to the old xy-system is

\( ({@ta1[1]@} ,{@ta1[2]@}) \)


(b) \( ({@x_b@}, {@y_b@}) \) :

\( x = {@x_b@} \cdot ({@a3@}) - ({@y_b@}) \cdot ({@a4@}) = {@ta2[1]@} \)

\( y = {@x_b@} \cdot ({@a4@}) + ({@y_b@}) \cdot ({@a3@}) = {@ta2[2]@} \)

So, the coordinates of this point with respect to the old xy-system is

\( ({@ta2[1]@}, {@ta2[2]@}) \)


(c) \( ({@x_c@},{@y_c@}) \) :

\( x = {@x_c@} \cdot ({@a3@}) - ({@y_c@}) \cdot ({@a4@}) = {@ta3[1]@} \)

\( y = {@x_c@} \cdot ({@a4@}) + ({@y_c@}) \cdot ({@a3@}) = {@ta3[2]@} \)

So, the coordinates of this point with respect to the old xy-system is

\( ({@ta3[1]@}, {@ta3[2]@}) \)


(d) \( ({@x_d@} ,{@y_d @}) \) :

\( x = {@x_d@} \cdot ({@a3@}) - ({@y_d@}) \cdot ({@a4@}) = {@ta4[1]@} \)

\( y = {@x_d@} \cdot ({@a4@}) + ({@y_d@}) \cdot ({@a3@}) = {@ta4[2]@} \)

So, the coordinates of this point with respect to the old xy-system is

\( ({@ta4[1]@}, {@ta4[2]@})\)
